entries.quote: ﻿17-04-25–04.32_101_Call_Holiday_Alibi
entries.speaker: Unknown

entries.quote: Summary
entries.speaker: Unknown

entries.quote: In this early morning 101 call, Ben Carter attempts to clarify the closure and handling of his July 2024 stalking report involving Alanna O’Hare. He provides a reference number (701211) and explains that PC Gore originally informed him the case would not be pursued as harassment, instead referring him to a charity. Despite clear recollections of submitting evidence and a police visit, the operator cannot locate a July incident at first—raising significant questions about data retention and continuity of case records. Eventually, it emerges that the July case is “the same” as the November stalking file, but inexplicably displays only the later date.
entries.speaker: Unknown

entries.quote: The call further reveals that every officer in the chain of command—PC Dixon, Sergeant Duffy, and Inspector Palmer—are on annual leave at the same time, leaving the caller with no supervisory recourse until their return. When Ben expresses that his alleged abuser is now living locally and asks who is accountable for providing safeguarding or updates, he’s told simply that “you’re not in immediate danger” and to call 999 if anything happens.
entries.speaker: Unknown

needs: Officer note re: suicide disclosure logging & correction

entries.quote: Access to Justice Obstructed by Staffing Patterns:
entries.speaker: Unknown

entries.quote: The victim discovers that all named officers and supervisors are on holiday simultaneously.
entries.speaker: Unknown

entries.quote: Despite being in an open stalking case with recent risk proximity, no alternative point of contact is offered before Tuesday 23rd April — effectively denying any safeguarding escalation.
entries.speaker: Unknown

entries.quote: No Operational Continuity:
entries.speaker: Unknown

entries.quote: Call handler refuses to transfer to anyone with authority, confirming they are not a police officer.
entries.speaker: Unknown

entries.quote: Ben is told Sussex Police cannot “keep going up the chain” — contradicting basic safeguarding escalation principles when multiple officers are unavailable.
entries.speaker: Unknown

entries.quote: Emotional Dismissal and Risk Deflection:
entries.speaker: Unknown

entries.quote: Despite disclosures of psychological fear, proximity to the alleged abuser, and failed updates, Ben is repeatedly advised “you’re not in immediate danger” as justification for doing nothing.
entries.speaker: Unknown

entries.quote: The phrase “justice goes on holiday” becomes literal — revealing institutional neglect disguised as procedure.
entries.speaker: Unknown

contradiction_summary.summary: Caller seeks clarity on a July-logged case; handler locates July call record but says the linked crime reference appears as November and remains 'under investigation'. Officer-in-charge (PC Jonathan Dixon) and both supervisors (Sgt Duffy, Insp Palmer) are confirmed on leave until Tuesday; handler says details cannot be discussed and advises 999 for emergencies.

police_position.availability: All on annual leave until Tuesday; email escalation to supervisor promised
police_position.disclosure: Handler states they lack authority to discuss details; will leave note for OIC
police_position.immediate_action_advice: Call 999 if you see the suspect or are in immediate danger

contradictions.claim: System displays July report but crime reference shows as November; handler cannot explain discrepancy while insisting it's one linked incident and 'under investigation'.
Caller states July case was closed; handler states it is 'under investigation' and 'not coming up on the system yet' as closed.
OIC (Dixon) and both supervisors (Duffy, Palmer) simultaneously on leave, leaving no informed contact for the victim.
Handler refuses to go through case details citing lack of authority and not being an officer; only offers to email OIC/supervisor and advises 999.
impact: Potential misuse of process to avoid updates
